Problem 1

Out of 100010001000 welds that have been made on a tower, it is suspected that 15%15\%15% are defective. To estimate ppp, the proportion of defective welds, how many welds must be inspected to have approximately 95%95\%95% confidence that the maximum error of the estimate of ppp is 0.040.040.04?

Solution.

Since we have a strong prior belief about the true proportion, we may use p^=0.15\widehat{p} = 0.15p​=0.15 in the confidence interval. The confidence interval in question is

p^±zα2p^(1−p^)n=p^±1.9600.15(1−0.15)n⏟standard error.\widehat{p} \pm z_{\frac{\alpha}{2}} \sqrt{\frac{\widehat{p}\p{1-\widehat{p}}}{n}} = \widehat{p} \pm \underbrace{1.960 \sqrt{\frac{0.15\p{1-0.15}}{n}}}_{\text{standard error}}.p​±z2α​​np​(1−p​)​​=p​±standard error1.960n0.15(1−0.15)​​​​.

For the standard error of the estimate to be at most 0.040.040.04, we need to solve

1.9600.15(1−0.15)n≤0.04  ⟹  n≥(1.9600.04)2⋅0.15(1−0.15)=306.1275.\begin{gathered} 1.960 \sqrt{\frac{0.15\p{1-0.15}}{n}} \leq 0.04 \\ \implies n \geq \p{\frac{1.960}{0.04}}^2 \cdot 0.15\p{1 - 0.15} = 306.1275. \end{gathered}1.960n0.15(1−0.15)​​≤0.04⟹n≥(0.041.960​)2⋅0.15(1−0.15)=306.1275.​

Thus, the smallest nnn that works is

n=307.\boxed{n = 307}.n=307​.

Problem 2

If X‾\mean{X}X and Y‾\mean{Y}Y are the respective means of two independent random samples of the same size nnn, find nnn if we want x‾−y‾±4\mean{x} - \mean{y} \pm 4x−y​±4 to be an approximate 90%90\%90% confidence interval for μX−μY\mu_X - \mu_YμX​−μY​. Assume that the standard deviations are known to be σX=15\sigma_X = 15σX​=15 and σY=25\sigma_Y = 25σY​=25.

Solution.

The confidence interval will be

x‾−y‾±zα2σX2n+σY2n=x‾−y‾±1.645152n+252n.\mean{x} - \mean{y} \pm z_{\frac{\alpha}{2}} \sqrt{\frac{\sigma_X^2}{n} + \frac{\sigma_Y^2}{n}} = \mean{x} - \mean{y} \pm 1.645 \sqrt{\frac{15^2}{n} + \frac{25^2}{n}}.x−y​±z2α​​nσX2​​+nσY2​​​=x−y​±1.645n152​+n252​​.

For x‾−y‾±4\mean{x} - \mean{y} \pm 4x−y​±4 to be an approximate 90%90\%90% confidence interval, we need the standard error to be at most 444, so we get

1.645152n+252n≤4  ⟹  n≥(1.6454)2⋅850=143.757578125n=144\begin{gathered} 1.645 \sqrt{\frac{15^2}{n} + \frac{25^2}{n}} \leq 4 \\ \implies n \geq \p{\frac{1.645}{4}}^2 \cdot 850 = 143.757578125 \\ \boxed{n = 144} \end{gathered}1.645n152​+n252​​≤4⟹n≥(41.645​)2⋅850=143.757578125n=144​​

Problem 3

A manufacturer sells a light bulb that has a mean life of 145014501450 hours with a standard deviation of 33.733.733.7 hours. A new manufacturing process is being tested, and there is interest in knowing the mean life of the new bulbs. How large a sample is required so that [x‾−5,x‾+5]\br{\mean{x} - 5, \mean{x} + 5}[x−5,x+5] is a 95%95\%95% confidence interval for μ\muμ? You may assume that the change in the standard deviation is minimal.

Solution.

Since the change in the standard deviation is minimal, we can use σ=33.7\sigma = 33.7σ=33.7 in the confidence interval and use a normal distribution. Like before, we need the standard error to be at most 555:

z0.025σn≤5  ⟹  n≥(1.9605)2⋅1135.69=174.51466816,z_{0.025} \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} \leq 5 \implies n \geq \p{\frac{1.960}{5}}^2 \cdot 1135.69 = 174.51466816,z0.025​n​σ​≤5⟹n≥(51.960​)2⋅1135.69=174.51466816,

so we use

n=175.\boxed{n = 175}.n=175​.

Problem 4

For a public opinion poll for a close presidential election, let ppp denote the proportion of voters who favor candidate AAA. How large a sample should be taken if we want the maximum error of the estimate of ppp to be equal to

  1. 0.030.030.03 with approximate 95%95\%95% confidence?
  2. 0.020.020.02 with approximate 95%95\%95% confidence?
Solution.

We have no information or guess on the true parameter ppp, so use the upper bound p(1−p)≤14p\p{1 - p} \leq \frac{1}{4}p(1−p)≤41​. We can bound

z0.025p(1−p)n≤1.96014n.z_{0.025} \sqrt{\frac{p\p{1 - p}}{n}} \leq 1.960 \sqrt{\frac{1}{4n}}.z0.025​np(1−p)​​≤1.9604n1​​.

To have the maximum error be less than some given ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, we need

1.96014n≤εn≥(1.960ε)2⋅14.\begin{aligned} 1.960\sqrt{\frac{1}{4n}} \leq \varepsilon \\ n \geq \p{\frac{1.960}{\varepsilon}}^2 \cdot \frac{1}{4}. \end{aligned}1.9604n1​​≤εn≥(ε1.960​)2⋅41​.​

  1. In this case, ε=0.03\varepsilon = 0.03ε=0.03, which gives

    n≥1067.11111111  ⟹  n=1068.n \geq 1067.11111111 \implies \boxed{n = 1068}.n≥1067.11111111⟹n=1068​.

  2. Similarly, ε=0.02\varepsilon = 0.02ε=0.02, so

    n≥2401  ⟹  n=2401.n \geq 2401 \implies \boxed{n = 2401}.n≥2401⟹n=2401​.

Problem 5

For n=12n = 12n=12 year-200720072007 model sedans whose horse-power is between 290290290 and 390390390, the following measurements give the time in seconds for the car to go from 000 to 60 mph60~\mathrm{mph}60 mph:

6.06.35.06.05.75.96.85.55.44.85.45.8\begin{array}{rrrrrrrrrrrr} 6.0 & 6.3 & 5.0 & 6.0 & 5.7 & 5.9 & 6.8 & 5.5 & 5.4 & 4.8 & 5.4 & 5.8 \end{array}6.0​6.3​5.0​6.0​5.7​5.9​6.8​5.5​5.4​4.8​5.4​5.8​
  1. Find a 96.14%96.14\%96.14% confidence interval for the median, mmm.
  2. The interval (y1,y7)\p{y_1, y_7}(y1​,y7​) could serve as a confidence interval for π0.3\pi_{0.3}π0.3​. Find it and give its confidence level.
Solution.

First, we need to sort the data to get the sample order statistics y1,…,y12y_1, \ldots, y_{12}y1​,…,y12​:

4.85.05.45.45.55.75.85.96.06.06.36.8y1y2y3y4y5y6y7y8y9y10y11y12\begin{array}{rrrrrrrrrrrr} 4.8 & 5.0 & 5.4 & 5.4 & 5.5 & 5.7 & 5.8 & 5.9 & 6.0 & 6.0 & 6.3 & 6.8 \\\hline y_1 & y_2 & y_3 & y_4 & y_5 & y_6 & y_7 & y_8 & y_9 & y_{10} & y_{11} & y_{12} \end{array}4.8y1​​5.0y2​​5.4y3​​5.4y4​​5.5y5​​5.7y6​​5.8y7​​5.9y8​​6.0y9​​6.0y10​​6.3y11​​6.8y12​​​

  1. From the textbook (or just from brute force), we know (i,j)=(3,10)\p{i, j} = \p{3, 10}(i,j)=(3,10) works.

    (y3,y10)=(5.4,6.0)\p{y_3, y_{10}} = \boxed{\p{5.4, 6.0}}(y3​,y10​)=(5.4,6.0)​

  2. The interval is

    (y1,y7)=(4.8,5.8).\p{y_1, y_7} = \boxed{\p{4.8, 5.8}}.(y1​,y7​)=(4.8,5.8)​.

    The confidence level is the probability the interval (Y1,Y7)\p{Y_1, Y_7}(Y1​,Y7​) contains π0.3\pi_{0.3}π0.3​:

    P(Y1<π0.3<Y7)=∑k=16(12k)(0.3)k(0.7)12−k=94.76%\P\p{Y_1 < \pi_{0.3} < Y_7} = \sum_{k=1}^6 \binom{12}{k} \p{0.3}^k \p{0.7}^{12-k} = \boxed{94.76\%}P(Y1​<π0.3​<Y7​)=k=1∑6​(k12​)(0.3)k(0.7)12−k=94.76%​
